Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: PPoSS: Planning: Integrated Scalable Platform for Privacy-aware Collaborative Learning and Inference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Building scalable distributed heterogeneous systems of the future with easy-to-program software is broadly acknowledged to be a grand challenge. It is widely recognized that a major disruption is currently under way in the design of computer systems as processors strive to extend, and go beyond, the end-game of Moore’s Law. This disruption is manifest in new forms of heterogeneous and distributed processors and memories at all scales (on-chip, on-die, on-node, on-rack, on-cluster, and on-data-center), rendering scalability as a fundamental challenge at all levels. Healthcare analytics offers a unique opportunity to explore scalable system design for the 21st century because there has been a tectonic shift in the ability of medical institutions to capture and store medical data, and to even stream data in real time. This shift has already contributed to an ecosystem of Machine Learning (ML) models being trained for a variety of clinical tasks. A new distributed heterogeneous architecture is required to build systems that can develop and deploy ML models based on distributed healthcare data that must necessarily be accessed with privacy-preserving constraints. Further, the proposed architecture must be accompanied by a software framework that can address the needs of domain-specific data scientists to develop and augment ML models being deployed in their hospitals.<br/><br/>This planning grant project is exploring the foundational principles necessary in building integrated scalable distributed systems of the future, so as to prepare for submitting a full proposal to the PPoSS program. It uses the domain of healthcare analytics to motivate and concretize the research agenda, but the principles developed in this research should be applicable to other application domains as well. The exploration focuses on demonstrating an integrated platform that spans multiple levels of distribution and heterogeneity of computation and storage, while also obeying important privacy constraints. While recent progress on the use of ML in healthcare applications has been encouraging, current approaches do not a) scale to the degrees of parallelism, heterogeneity, and distribution that will be required in future systems, or b) support the soft real-time responsiveness to streaming data that is needed in many clinical situations. The originality of this project can be seen in the integration of distribution, heterogeneity, and privacy considerations in a single unified software/hardware stack, which includes adaptive resource management that spans privacy-preserving federated continuous learning, automatic specialization of ML models at individual sites, and automatic selection of ML models best suited for specific clinical tasks that maximize accuracy subject to different latency and soft real-time constraints.<br/><br/>This project’s end-to-end approach to develop foundational scalability principles will impact multiple areas of computer science through publications, tutorials and courses, thereby benefiting other researchers working on scalability challenges in future distributed heterogeneous systems. The use of healthcare analytics as a driving application has the potential to result in significant benefits to society, by demonstrating how knowledge distilled from multiple sources of data can be embodied in recommendation systems that can run onsite to provide time-critical decision support to physicians. As a further impact, the project will contribute to the training of Highly Qualified Personnel (HQP) at the intersection of Systems for ML and ML for Healthcare — two emerging inter-disciplinary communities that are currently growing independent of each other. Finally, this research will leverage existing activities at the PIs’ institutions that contribute to broadening participation of underrepresented groups in computing.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Machine Learning (ML) has revolutionized various fields, including healthcare. ML algorithms can analyze vast amounts of patient data to detect patterns, make predictions, and provide personalized care. However, implementing ML in healthcare requires a robust framework that is efficient, scalable, and privacy-preserving.

To tackle this challenge, a team of computer scientists from three institutions - Georgia Tech, UIUC, and Berkeley - have developed a framework that can support the production and consumption of ML functionality in a way that is efficient, privacy-preserving, heterogeneity-aware, and scalable. This framework aims to make ML more accessible to non-experts, particularly healthcare data analysts.

One of the most significant outcomes of this project is the proposed framework for hospitals, with the capability to perform on-site ML model training and deployment for healthcare prediction tasks. This can enable doctors to make better diagnoses and provide timely interventions. For instance, the system can detect critical conditions such as septic shock, respiratory distress, and heart failure earlier, potentially saving human lives.

The team has also developed preliminary building blocks for the training and inference framework, which includes developing a team and technological tools that can abstract away lower-level Distributed Systems and ML training details. The project can enable healthcare data analysts to specialize in healthcare data analytics and train Deep Learning (DL) models to higher levels of accuracy as more clinical sites can participate in training in a privacy-preserving fashion.

The proposed framework is capable of making tradeoffs between model accuracy and latency in time-critical situations. For example, the timeliness of predictions is as important as their accuracy in critical conditions. The system can make faster predictions, leading to earlier interventions and better patient outcomes.

The development of this framework has significant implications for the medical profession and patient care. It can support medical decision-making and provide personalized care to patients. The project can potentially improve the accuracy of healthcare prediction models, increase the throughput of the proposed inference framework, and save human lives. With the growth of Electronic Health Records (EHR) and waveform availability, which tracks various human conditions, a new brand of a data analyst specializing in healthcare data analytics is required. This project enables healthcare data analysts with technological tools that can abstract away lower-level Distributed Systems and ML training details, which data analysts commonly do not possess.

In conclusion, the proposed framework can revolutionize the healthcare sector by providing timely interventions and better patient outcomes, supporting medical decision-making, and enabling healthcare data analysts to specialize in healthcare data analytics.
